description: From Middle English champioun, from Old French champion, from Medieval Latin campio (“combatant in a duel, champion”), from Frankish *kampijō (“fighter”), from Proto-West Germanic *kampijō (“combat soldier”), a derivative of Proto-West Germanic *kampijan (“to battle, to campaign”), itself a derivative of Proto-West Germanic *kamp (“battlefield, battle”), ultimately a borrowing in West-Germanic from Latin campus (“a field, a plain, a place of action”).

entries.meaning: (attributive) Acting as a champion; having defeated all one's competitors.
(predicative, Ireland, Britain, dialect) Excellent; brilliant; superb; deserving of high praise.
An ongoing winner in a game or contest.
examples: The defending champion is expected to defeat his challenger.

entries.meaning: Someone who is chosen to represent a group of people in a contest.
examples: Barcelona is eligible to play in FIFA Club World Cup as the champion of Europe.

entries.meaning: Someone who fights for a cause or status.
examples: Emmeline Pankhurst was a champion of women's suffrage.

entries.meaning: Someone who fights on another's behalf.
(botany) A particularly notable member of a plant species, such as one of great size.

verbs.description: champion (third-person singular simple present champions, present participle championing, simple past and past participle championed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To promote, advocate, or act as a champion for (a cause, etc.).
